Topic.Title: Shield now $299

Message.Msg: later today, NVIDIA will announce that their SHIELD handheld — a hybrid PC and Android game console — will shed $50 from its price tag when it launches on Thursday, June 27. “Feedback from gamers is why SHIELD’s triggers have the perfect throw length. Why SHIELD’s buttons have just the right amount of give. Why SHIELD’s thumb sticks are so satisfying to flick,” writes NVIDIA. Over the course of trade shows like E3 and CES, thousands of gamers and members of the press have provided feedback to NVIDIA about the console’s capabilities and its price point. Originally announced at $349, NVIDIA proclaims that this critical group (including this author) told them they’d “have a home run” at $299.

Message.Title: Watch for another move to 15, late today or tomorrow.
Message.Msg: I only have a few minutes but I'd just like to say that I expect another move to 15, or higher, later today or tomorrow. Given the market has dropped over 400 points, the last two days, and NVDA is UP during that time period, and given that the shorts have been given one last chance to cover, ANY bounce in the overall market should propel the stock back to that level or higher. I doubt there are any other semis that are up for this 2 day period, and I would guess the company is going to be back in buying (if they're not already), since THEY know that they're going to blow the numbers out of the water when the next earnings report comes. As always, we'll know in the fullness of time. Max

Topic.Title: Shield now $299

Message.Msg: From a new article by Jon Peddie: "We've heard from thousands of gamers that if the price was $299, we'd have a home run," said Jason Paul, product line manager of GeForce GPUs in a blog post Thursday. Those who pre-ordered the Shield will be charged the new, lower price when the product ships. Microsoft, meanwhile, said Wednesday it would reverse some unpopular policies it recently announced for its coming Xbox One videogame console. The company said it would no longer require its Xbox to connect to the Internet each day, nor would it restrict how its videogame discs are traded, resold or rented. __ Peddie also said that Shield is intended as a proof of concept - not at a loss - as well as a "peripheral for cloud streaming". Many birds with one stone.

Message.Title: "Advanced Micro Devices: The Chipmaker Of The Future?"
Message.Msg: "Advanced Micro Devices: The Chipmaker Of The Future?" ... "Pure Speculation: I'd like to take a minute just to speculate. Let's say that Apple does make the switch back to AMD graphics for the entire Mac lineup. Where's the evidence? Well there is no evidence per se, but conjecture (and lots of it): Many were suspecting a MacBook Pro refresh at Apple's recently held WWDC; we didn't get one. There's really no reason why Apple shouldn't have announced a refreshed MacBook Pro except for one: production bottlenecks. One component of particular interest is the display; it's very well possible that Apple had production issues with the high-end display that goes into the MacBook Pro with Retina Display. That is the most logical explanation, but it may not be the only. What if Apple is waiting for a certain chipmaker, who's taking on the very difficult task of restructuring, to supply components? AMD, after all, has a great deal on its plate at the moment (as you'll see in the next section), which could be a possible explanation of the delay in the announcement of the next-generation MacBook Pro family. Again, this is all conjecture, though logical in my mind. So, on the off chance that this is the case, what would that mean for AMD? Well, going along with the theme of market share, it would simply mean more market share. This is crucial for AMD right now, and while winning back Cupertino's love wouldn't significantly help the company's bottom line, it serves as an indicator of AMD's competitive viability." source: seeking alpha

Message.Title: AMD unlikely to follow NVIDIA to license its graphic technologies
Message.Msg: SOURCE: x-bit Labs ""The differences between AMD’s and Nvidia’s business approaches are obvious: if Nvidia plans to allow others to integrate its graphics architecture into a wide range of application processors, then AMD wants to design chips with third-party IP for various markets. Nvidia’s approach allows the company’s technologies to be in the infinite number of devices; whereas AMD’s approach is bound to the company’s abilities to design semi-custom chips, which limits the addressable market to several large-scale contracts per year. "" There is a huge danger (in AMD's case) to depend your future on a handful of big companies - if one of them leaves, you'll be instantly 20% or more less in revenues. Rory Read is effectively digging a hole for AMD to disappear into....

Topic.Title: AMD unlikely to follow NVIDIA to license its graphic technologies

Message.Msg: Companies will adopt Nvidia's design -- Proliferation of Tegra zone -- Standardization -- The slow to adopt company will be forced to catch up to adopt Nvidia's design. [Nvidia continuously expand IP] Somewhere in there, AMD becomes irrelevant. If they survive, fight is now back to CPU design. Disruption occurs, and a new leader emerges. IP is still King (IBM).

Message.Title: stupid markets...getting the fed out of the equation is what we need
Message.Msg: once the morons realize that by the fed getting out of the market forces and letting good old fashion capitalism determine the fate of our country, things will be off to the races again. did everybody think the fed was going to buy 85 billion a month for infinity? He's still not going to even think about raising the fed funds rate until like 2015...if the 10 year goes to even 3 percent, that is still historically low and mortage rates in the mid 4 to 5 range aren't exactly a bad deal either. The traders will benefit from the volatility but for those of us with a longer horizon, the general trend is still up. things are getting slightly better each quarter and corporate profits remain healthy. god forbid our government actual passes legislation to fix the problems we have. if there was any progress in Washington at all, things would already be a lot better. for those that bought today, they are getting a great deal as I see no reason why we will not rally back to the mid 15's on the good rebound days. I also think they were smart to sacrifice a little profit margin on shield to sell more units. its about establishing the platform and then having others follow. if they can get developers to build specifically for tegra, it gives them a market differentiator over qualcom because they have not gamer relationship...hell they can't even get drivers for windows to work right. I think the second half of the year is going to be great for NVidia. lots of irons in the fire.
